qas.question: What positive integer is used to divide the sum of two positive integers in modular mathematics?
What type of device can be use to demonstrate modular addition?
How many integers are divided in modular arithmetic?
What are the two integers called?
What is the result of the remained of the division?
If the hour hand is on 1 and is advanced by 4 hours, where does it end up?

context: In modular <b3_0>arithmetic<b3_0/>, two integers are added and then the sum is divided by a positive integer called <a0_0><b4_0>the modulus<b4_0/><a0_0/>. The result of <b5_0>modular addition<b5_0/> is <a1_0>the remainder of that division<a1_0/>. For any modulus, n, the set of integers from 0 to n − 1 forms a group under modular addition: the inverse of any element a is n − a, and 0 is the <b6_0>identity element<b6_0/>. This is familiar from the addition of hours on the face of <a2_0>a clock<a2_0/>: if the hour hand is on <b7_0>9<b7_0/> and is advanced 4 hours, it ends up on 1, as shown at the right. This is expressed by saying that 9 + 4 equals 1 "modulo 12" or, in symbols,
